comment_text.mn65:2.1: The practice of eating one meal a day is encouraged but not required by Vinaya. At MN 21:7.4 the Buddha reminisced about the days when he merely needed to mention it and monks would follow suit. | In the related story at MN 70:1.3, the Buddha encouraged not eating at night, to which monks also objected, occasioning the laying down of a Vinaya rule (Bu Pc 37), although at least some of the monks later came to regret their objections, recognizing that the Buddha had acted for their welfare (MN 66:6.4).
comment_text.mn65:3.1: Bhaddāli does not appear elsewhere in early texts.
comment_text.mn65:3.3: The commentary says that he feared he would not be able to sustain his monkhood. Chinese parallels at this point indicate that he feared discomfort (EA 49.7 at T ii 800b29, T 1425 at T xxii 359b14).
comment_text.mn65:4.2: Ekāsano here in Mahāsaṅgīti edition appears superfluous, as it is missing in most editions.
comment_text.mn65:4.6: “Would not see the Buddha face to face” is a loose rendering of na bhagavato sammukhībhāvaṁ adāsi. The idiom can be captured more literally at DN 3:2.6.2; when King Pasenadi meets Pokkharasāti, he does not “grant him an audience face to face” (tassa … sammukhībhāvampi na dadāti) but only behind a curtain.
comment_text.mn65:8.1: When someone genuinely confesses, the Buddha makes a point to acknowledge what they had done, without dismissing it and thereby discounting the inner work they had achieved to get to this point.
comment_text.mn65:11.2: This set of seven noble disciples is detailed at MN 70:14.1.
comment_text.mn65:22.2: Read pavayha per MN 122:27.3 for Mahāsaṅgīti’s pasayha here. | Vinaya matters are dealt with separately by the monks and nuns, hence I use “monk” rather than “mendicant” here.
comment_text.mn65:27.4: This reads like a broken sentence; they got half way through, then realized the implications of what they were saying.
comment_text.mn65:29.1: This question was also asked by Kassapa at SN 16.13.
comment_text.mn65:30.2: This echoes the Buddha’s words to Sāriputta at Bu Pj 1:3.4.6.
comment_text.mn65:32.1: While there are many suttas on a thoroughbred, the simile taught here does not appear elsewhere in the Pali canon. Perhaps this is in reference to MN 107:3.2, which, however, only has one line in common.
comment_text.mn65:33.3: For the phrase tasmiṁ ṭhāne parinibbāyati (“its bad behavior is extinguished”, literally “it is extinguished regarding that state”) I follow the commentary, which specifies that tasmiṁ ṭhāne refers to the twists and dodges that cease rather than the good habits that are developed.
comment_text.mn65:33.7: Rājaguṇe occurs in Mil 5.1.4, where it distinguishes royal officials from ordinary ones. I take it and rājavaṁse to refer to “the protocols and traditions of court” rather than “kingly qualities”.

root_text.mn65:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
root_text.mn65:2.2: ekāsanabhojanaṁ kho, ahaṁ, bhikkhave, bhuñjamāno appābādhatañca sañjānāmi appātaṅkatañca lahuṭṭhānañca balañca phāsuvihārañca.
root_text.mn65:2.4: ekāsanabhojanaṁ kho, bhikkhave, tumhepi bhuñjamānā appābādhatañca sañjānissatha appātaṅkatañca lahuṭṭhānañca balañca phāsuvihārañcā”ti.
root_text.mn65:3.1: Evaṁ vutte, āyasmā bhaddāli bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn65:3.2: “ahaṁ kho, bhante, na ussahāmi ekāsanabhojanaṁ bhuñjituṁ;
root_text.mn65:3.3: ekāsanabhojanañhi me, bhante, bhuñjato siyā kukkuccaṁ, siyā vippaṭisāro”ti.
root_text.mn65:4.1: “Tena hi tvaṁ, bhaddāli, yattha nimantito assasi tattha ekadesaṁ bhuñjitvā ekadesaṁ nīharitvāpi bhuñjeyyāsi.
root_text.mn65:4.2: Evampi kho tvaṁ, bhaddāli, bhuñjamāno ekāsano yāpessasī”ti.
root_text.mn65:4.3: “Evampi kho ahaṁ, bhante, na ussahāmi bhuñjituṁ;
root_text.mn65:4.4: evampi hi me, bhante, bhuñjato siyā kukkuccaṁ, siyā vippaṭisāro”ti.
root_text.mn65:4.5: Atha kho āyasmā bhaddāli bhagavatā sikkhāpade paññāpiyamāne bhikkhusaṅghe sikkhaṁ samādiyamāne anussāhaṁ pavedesi.
root_text.mn65:4.6: Atha kho āyasmā bhaddāli sabbaṁ taṁ temāsaṁ na bhagavato sammukhībhāvaṁ adāsi, yathā taṁ satthusāsane sikkhāya aparipūrakārī.
root_text.mn65:5.1: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā bhikkhū bhagavato cīvarakammaṁ karonti—
root_text.mn65:6.1: Atha kho āyasmā bhaddāli yena te bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā tehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṁ sammodi.
root_text.mn65:6.2: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho āyasmantaṁ bhaddāliṁ te bhikkhū etadavocuṁ:
root_text.mn65:6.3: “idaṁ kho, āvuso bhaddāli, bhagavato cīvarakammaṁ karīyati.
root_text.mn65:6.5: Iṅghāvuso bhaddāli, etaṁ dosakaṁ sādhukaṁ manasi karohi, mā te pacchā dukkarataraṁ ahosī”ti.
root_text.mn65:7.1: “Evamāvuso”ti kho āyasmā bhaddāli tesaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā bhaddāli bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn65:7.2: “accayo maṁ, bhante, accagamā yathābālaṁ yathāmūḷhaṁ yathāakusalaṁ, yohaṁ bhagavatā sikkhāpade paññāpiyamāne bhikkhusaṅghe sikkhaṁ samādiyamāne anussāhaṁ pavedesiṁ.
root_text.mn65:7.3: Tassa me, bhante, bhagavā accayaṁ accayato paṭiggaṇhātu āyatiṁ saṁvarāyā”ti.
root_text.mn65:8.1: “Taggha tvaṁ, bhaddāli, accayo accagamā yathābālaṁ yathāmūḷhaṁ yathāakusalaṁ, yaṁ tvaṁ mayā sikkhāpade paññāpiyamāne bhikkhusaṅghe sikkhaṁ samādiyamāne anussāhaṁ pavedesi.
root_text.mn65:9.1: Samayopi kho te, bhaddāli, appaṭividdho ahosi:
root_text.mn65:9.2: ‘bhagavā kho sāvatthiyaṁ viharati, bhagavāpi maṁ jānissati—
root_text.mn65:9.3: bhaddāli nāma bhikkhu satthusāsane sikkhāya aparipūrakārī’ti.
root_text.mn65:9.4: Ayampi kho te, bhaddāli, samayo appaṭividdho ahosi.
root_text.mn65:9.5: Samayopi kho te, bhaddāli, appaṭividdho ahosi:
root_text.mn65:9.6: ‘sambahulā kho bhikkhū sāvatthiyaṁ vassaṁ upagatā, tepi maṁ jānissanti—
root_text.mn65:9.7: bhaddāli nāma bhikkhu satthusāsane sikkhāya aparipūrakārī’ti.
root_text.mn65:9.8: Ayampi kho te, bhaddāli, samayo appaṭividdho ahosi.
root_text.mn65:9.9: Samayopi kho te, bhaddāli, appaṭividdho ahosi:
root_text.mn65:9.10: ‘sambahulā kho bhikkhuniyo sāvatthiyaṁ vassaṁ upagatā, tāpi maṁ jānissanti—
root_text.mn65:9.11: bhaddāli nāma bhikkhu satthusāsane sikkhāya aparipūrakārī’ti.
root_text.mn65:9.12: Ayampi kho te, bhaddāli, samayo appaṭividdho ahosi.
root_text.mn65:9.13: Samayopi kho te, bhaddāli, appaṭividdho ahosi:
root_text.mn65:9.14: ‘sambahulā kho upāsakā sāvatthiyaṁ paṭivasanti, tepi maṁ jānissanti—
root_text.mn65:9.15: bhaddāli nāma bhikkhu satthusāsane sikkhāya aparipūrakārī’ti.
root_text.mn65:9.16: Ayampi kho te, bhaddāli, samayo appaṭividdho ahosi.
root_text.mn65:9.17: Samayopi kho te, bhaddāli, appaṭividdho ahosi:
root_text.mn65:9.18: ‘sambahulā kho upāsikā sāvatthiyaṁ paṭivasanti, tāpi maṁ jānissanti—
root_text.mn65:9.19: bhaddāli nāma bhikkhu satthusāsane sikkhāya aparipūrakārī’ti.
root_text.mn65:9.20: Ayampi kho te, bhaddāli, samayo appaṭividdho ahosi.
root_text.mn65:9.21: Samayopi kho te, bhaddāli, appaṭividdho ahosi:
root_text.mn65:9.22: ‘sambahulā kho nānātitthiyā samaṇabrāhmaṇā sāvatthiyaṁ vassaṁ upagatā, tepi maṁ jānissanti—
root_text.mn65:9.23: bhaddāli nāma bhikkhu samaṇassa gotamassa sāvako theraññataro bhikkhu sāsane sikkhāya aparipūrakārī’ti.
root_text.mn65:9.24: Ayampi kho te, bhaddāli, samayo appaṭividdho ahosī”ti.
root_text.mn65:10.1: “Accayo maṁ, bhante, accagamā yathābālaṁ yathāmūḷhaṁ yathāakusalaṁ, yohaṁ bhagavatā sikkhāpade paññāpiyamāne bhikkhusaṅghe sikkhaṁ samādiyamāne anussāhaṁ pavedesiṁ.
root_text.mn65:10.2: Tassa me, bhante, bhagavā accayaṁ accayato paṭiggaṇhātu āyatiṁ saṁvarāyā”ti.
root_text.mn65:10.3: “Taggha tvaṁ, bhaddāli, accayo accagamā yathābālaṁ yathāmūḷhaṁ yathāakusalaṁ, yaṁ tvaṁ mayā sikkhāpade paññāpiyamāne bhikkhusaṅghe sikkhaṁ samādiyamāne anussāhaṁ pavedesi.
root_text.mn65:11.2: idhassa bhikkhu ubhatobhāgavimutto, tamahaṁ evaṁ vadeyyaṁ:
root_text.mn65:11.3: ‘ehi me tvaṁ, bhikkhu, paṅke saṅkamo hohī’ti, api nu kho so saṅkameyya vā aññena vā kāyaṁ sannāmeyya, ‘no’ti vā vadeyyā”ti?
root_text.mn65:11.12: ‘ehi me tvaṁ, bhikkhu, paṅke saṅkamo hohī’ti, api nu kho so saṅkameyya vā aññena vā kāyaṁ sannāmeyya, ‘no’ti vā vadeyyā”ti?
root_text.mn65:12.2: api nu tvaṁ, bhaddāli, tasmiṁ samaye ubhatobhāgavimutto vā hosi paññāvimutto vā kāyasakkhi vā diṭṭhippatto vā saddhāvimutto vā dhammānusārī vā saddhānusārī vā”ti?
root_text.mn65:12.4: “Nanu tvaṁ, bhaddāli, tasmiṁ samaye ritto tuccho aparaddho”ti?
root_text.mn65:13.2: Accayo maṁ, bhante, accagamā yathābālaṁ yathāmūḷhaṁ yathāakusalaṁ, yohaṁ bhagavatā sikkhāpade paññāpiyamāne bhikkhusaṅghe sikkhaṁ samādiyamāne anussāhaṁ pavedesiṁ.
root_text.mn65:13.3: Tassa me, bhante, bhagavā accayaṁ accayato paṭiggaṇhātu āyatiṁ saṁvarāyā”ti.
root_text.mn65:13.4: “Taggha tvaṁ, bhaddāli, accayo accagamā yathābālaṁ yathāmūḷhaṁ yathāakusalaṁ, yaṁ tvaṁ mayā sikkhāpade paññāpiyamāne bhikkhusaṅghe sikkhaṁ samādiyamāne anussāhaṁ pavedesi.
root_text.mn65:13.5: Yato ca kho tvaṁ, bhaddāli, accayaṁ accayato disvā yathādhammaṁ paṭikarosi, taṁ te mayaṁ paṭiggaṇhāma.
root_text.mn65:13.6: Vuddhihesā, bhaddāli, ariyassa vinaye yo accayaṁ accayato disvā yathādhammaṁ paṭikaroti, āyatiṁ saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.
root_text.mn65:14.1: Idha, bhaddāli, ekacco bhikkhu satthusāsane sikkhāya aparipūrakārī hoti.
root_text.mn65:14.3: ‘yannūnāhaṁ vivittaṁ senāsanaṁ bhajeyyaṁ araññaṁ rukkhamūlaṁ pabbataṁ kandaraṁ giriguhaṁ susānaṁ vanapatthaṁ abbhokāsaṁ palālapuñjaṁ.
root_text.mn65:14.4: Appeva nāmāhaṁ uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanavisesaṁ sacchikareyyan’ti.
root_text.mn65:14.5: So vivittaṁ senāsanaṁ bhajati araññaṁ rukkhamūlaṁ pabbataṁ kandaraṁ giriguhaṁ susānaṁ vanapatthaṁ abbhokāsaṁ palālapuñjaṁ.
root_text.mn65:14.6: Tassa tathāvūpakaṭṭhassa viharato satthāpi upavadati, anuviccapi viññū sabrahmacārī upavadanti, devatāpi upavadanti, attāpi attānaṁ upavadati.
root_text.mn65:14.7: So satthārāpi upavadito, anuviccapi viññūhi sabrahmacārīhi upavadito, devatāhipi upavadito, attanāpi attānaṁ upavadito na uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanavisesaṁ sacchikaroti.
root_text.mn65:14.9: Evañhi taṁ, bhaddāli, hoti yathā taṁ satthusāsane sikkhāya aparipūrakārissa.
root_text.mn65:15.1: Idha pana, bhaddāli, ekacco bhikkhu satthusāsane sikkhāya paripūrakārī hoti.
root_text.mn65:15.3: ‘yannūnāhaṁ vivittaṁ senāsanaṁ bhajeyyaṁ araññaṁ rukkhamūlaṁ pabbataṁ kandaraṁ giriguhaṁ susānaṁ vanapatthaṁ abbhokāsaṁ palālapuñjaṁ.
root_text.mn65:15.4: Appeva nāmāhaṁ uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanavisesaṁ sacchikareyyan’ti.
root_text.mn65:15.5: So vivittaṁ senāsanaṁ bhajati araññaṁ rukkhamūlaṁ pabbataṁ kandaraṁ giriguhaṁ susānaṁ vanapatthaṁ abbhokāsaṁ palālapuñjaṁ.
root_text.mn65:15.6: Tassa tathāvūpakaṭṭhassa viharato satthāpi na upavadati, anuviccapi viññū sabrahmacārī na upavadanti, devatāpi na upavadanti, attāpi attānaṁ na upavadati.
root_text.mn65:15.7: So satthārāpi anupavadito, anuviccapi viññūhi sabrahmacārīhi anupavadito, devatāhipi anupavadito, attanāpi attānaṁ anupavadito uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanavisesaṁ sacchikaroti.
root_text.mn65:16.1: So vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn65:16.3: Evañhi taṁ, bhaddāli, hoti yathā taṁ satthusāsane sikkhāya paripūrakārissa.
root_text.mn65:17.1: Puna caparaṁ, bhaddāli, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn65:17.3: Evañhi taṁ, bhaddāli, hoti yathā taṁ satthusāsane sikkhāya paripūrakārissa.
root_text.mn65:17.4: Puna caparaṁ, bhaddāli, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati, sato ca sampajāno sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṁvedeti, yaṁ taṁ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn65:17.6: Evañhi taṁ, bhaddāli, hoti yathā taṁ satthusāsane sikkhāya paripūrakārissa.
root_text.mn65:17.7: Puna caparaṁ, bhaddāli, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn65:17.9: Evañhi taṁ, bhaddāli, hoti yathā taṁ satthusāsane sikkhāya paripūrakārissa.
root_text.mn65:18.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn65:18.2: So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati.
root_text.mn65:18.4: Evañhi taṁ, bhaddāli, hoti yathā taṁ satthusāsane sikkhāya paripūrakārissa.
root_text.mn65:19.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte sattānaṁ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn65:19.2: So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti: ‘ime vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā …pe… vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapannā; ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā …pe… sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapannā’ti iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena …pe… yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
root_text.mn65:19.4: Evañhi taṁ, bhaddāli, hoti yathā taṁ satthusāsane sikkhāya paripūrakārissa.
root_text.mn65:20.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṁ khayañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn65:20.2: So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti;
root_text.mn65:20.3: ‘ime āsavā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
root_text.mn65:21.1: Tassa evaṁ jānato evaṁ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati.
root_text.mn65:21.3: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
root_text.mn65:21.5: Evañhi taṁ, bhaddāli, hoti yathā taṁ satthusāsane sikkhāya paripūrakārissā”ti.
root_text.mn65:22.1: Evaṁ vutte, āyasmā bhaddāli bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn65:22.2: “ko nu kho, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo yena midhekaccaṁ bhikkhuṁ pasayha pasayha kāraṇaṁ karonti?
root_text.mn65:22.3: Ko pana, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo yena midhekaccaṁ bhikkhuṁ no tathā pasayha pasayha kāraṇaṁ karontī”ti?
root_text.mn65:23.1: “Idha, bhaddāli, ekacco bhikkhu abhiṇhāpattiko hoti āpattibahulo.
root_text.mn65:23.2: So bhikkhūhi vuccamāno aññenaññaṁ paṭicarati, bahiddhā kathaṁ apanāmeti, kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti, na sammā vattati, na lomaṁ pāteti, na netthāraṁ vattati, ‘yena saṅgho attamano hoti taṁ karomī’ti nāha.
root_text.mn65:23.5: So bhikkhūhi vuccamāno aññenaññaṁ paṭicarati, bahiddhā kathaṁ apanāmeti, kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti, na sammā vattati, na lomaṁ pāteti, na netthāraṁ vattati, “yena saṅgho attamano hoti taṁ karomī”ti nāha.
root_text.mn65:23.6: Sādhu vatāyasmanto imassa bhikkhuno tathā tathā upaparikkhatha yathāssidaṁ adhikaraṇaṁ na khippameva vūpasameyyā’ti.
root_text.mn65:23.7: Tassa kho evaṁ, bhaddāli, bhikkhuno bhikkhū tathā tathā upaparikkhanti yathāssidaṁ adhikaraṇaṁ na khippameva vūpasammati.
root_text.mn65:24.1: Idha pana, bhaddāli, ekacco bhikkhu abhiṇhāpattiko hoti āpattibahulo.
root_text.mn65:24.2: So bhikkhūhi vuccamāno nāññenaññaṁ paṭicarati, bahiddhā kathaṁ na apanāmeti, na kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti, sammā vattati, lomaṁ pāteti, netthāraṁ vattati, ‘yena saṅgho attamano hoti taṁ karomī’ti āha.
root_text.mn65:24.5: So bhikkhūhi vuccamāno nāññenaññaṁ paṭicarati, bahiddhā kathaṁ na apanāmeti, na kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti, sammā vattati, lomaṁ pāteti, netthāraṁ vattati, “yena saṅgho attamano hoti taṁ karomī”ti āha.
root_text.mn65:24.6: Sādhu vatāyasmanto, imassa bhikkhuno tathā tathā upaparikkhatha yathāssidaṁ adhikaraṇaṁ khippameva vūpasameyyā’ti.
root_text.mn65:24.7: Tassa kho evaṁ, bhaddāli, bhikkhuno bhikkhū tathā tathā upaparikkhanti yathāssidaṁ adhikaraṇaṁ khippameva vūpasammati.
root_text.mn65:25.1: Idha, bhaddāli, ekacco bhikkhu adhiccāpattiko hoti anāpattibahulo.
root_text.mn65:25.2: So bhikkhūhi vuccamāno aññenaññaṁ paṭicarati, bahiddhā kathaṁ apanāmeti, kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti, na sammā vattati, na lomaṁ pāteti, na netthāraṁ vattati, ‘yena saṅgho attamano hoti taṁ karomī’ti nāha.
root_text.mn65:25.5: So bhikkhūhi vuccamāno aññenaññaṁ paṭicarati, bahiddhā kathaṁ apanāmeti, kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti, na sammā vattati, na lomaṁ pāteti, na netthāraṁ vattati, “yena saṅgho attamano hoti taṁ karomī”ti nāha.
root_text.mn65:25.6: Sādhu vatāyasmanto, imassa bhikkhuno tathā tathā upaparikkhatha yathāssidaṁ adhikaraṇaṁ na khippameva vūpasameyyā’ti.
root_text.mn65:25.7: Tassa kho evaṁ, bhaddāli, bhikkhuno bhikkhū tathā tathā upaparikkhanti yathāssidaṁ adhikaraṇaṁ na khippameva vūpasammati.
root_text.mn65:26.1: Idha pana, bhaddāli, ekacco bhikkhu adhiccāpattiko hoti anāpattibahulo.
root_text.mn65:26.2: So bhikkhūhi vuccamāno nāññenaññaṁ paṭicarati, na bahiddhā kathaṁ apanāmeti, na kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti, sammā vattati, lomaṁ pāteti, netthāraṁ vattati, ‘yena saṅgho attamano hoti taṁ karomī’ti āha.
root_text.mn65:26.5: So bhikkhūhi vuccamāno nāññenaññaṁ paṭicarati, na bahiddhā kathaṁ apanāmeti, na kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti, sammā vattati, lomaṁ pāteti, netthāraṁ vattati, “yena saṅgho attamano hoti taṁ karomī”ti āha.
root_text.mn65:26.6: Sādhu vatāyasmanto, imassa bhikkhuno tathā tathā upaparikkhatha yathāssidaṁ adhikaraṇaṁ khippameva vūpasameyyā’ti.
root_text.mn65:26.7: Tassa kho evaṁ, bhaddāli, bhikkhuno bhikkhū tathā tathā upaparikkhanti yathāssidaṁ adhikaraṇaṁ khippameva vūpasammati.
root_text.mn65:27.1: Idha, bhaddāli, ekacco bhikkhu saddhāmattakena vahati pemamattakena.
root_text.mn65:27.3: ‘ayaṁ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu saddhāmattakena vahati pemamattakena.
root_text.mn65:27.4: Sace mayaṁ imaṁ bhikkhuṁ pasayha pasayha kāraṇaṁ karissāma—
root_text.mn65:27.5: mā yampissa taṁ saddhāmattakaṁ pemamattakaṁ tamhāpi parihāyī’ti.
root_text.mn65:28.1: Seyyathāpi, bhaddāli, purisassa ekaṁ cakkhuṁ, tassa mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā taṁ ekaṁ cakkhuṁ rakkheyyuṁ:
root_text.mn65:28.2: ‘mā yampissa taṁ ekaṁ cakkhuṁ tamhāpi parihāyī’ti;
root_text.mn65:28.3: evameva kho, bhaddāli, idhekacco bhikkhu saddhāmattakena vahati pemamattakena.
root_text.mn65:28.5: ‘ayaṁ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu saddhāmattakena vahati pemamattakena.
root_text.mn65:28.6: Sace mayaṁ imaṁ bhikkhuṁ pasayha pasayha kāraṇaṁ karissāma—
root_text.mn65:28.7: mā yampissa taṁ saddhāmattakaṁ pemamattakaṁ tamhāpi parihāyī’ti.
root_text.mn65:28.8: Ayaṁ kho, bhaddāli, hetu ayaṁ paccayo yena midhekaccaṁ bhikkhuṁ pasayha pasayha kāraṇaṁ karonti.
root_text.mn65:28.9: Ayaṁ pana, bhaddāli, hetu ayaṁ paccayo, yena midhekaccaṁ bhikkhuṁ no tathā pasayha pasayha kāraṇaṁ karontī”ti.
root_text.mn65:29.1: “Ko nu kho, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo yena pubbe appatarāni ceva sikkhāpadāni ahesuṁ bahutarā ca bhikkhū aññāya saṇṭhahiṁsu?
root_text.mn65:29.2: Ko pana, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo yena etarahi bahutarāni ceva sikkhāpadāni honti appatarā ca bhikkhū aññāya saṇṭhahantī”ti?
root_text.mn65:30.1: “Evametaṁ, bhaddāli, hoti sattesu hāyamānesu, saddhamme antaradhāyamāne, bahutarāni ceva sikkhāpadāni honti appatarā ca bhikkhū aññāya saṇṭhahantīti.
root_text.mn65:30.2: Na tāva, bhaddāli, satthā sāvakānaṁ sikkhāpadaṁ paññāpeti yāva na idhekacce āsavaṭṭhānīyā dhammā saṅghe pātubhavanti.
root_text.mn65:30.3: Yato ca kho, bhaddāli, idhekacce āsavaṭṭhānīyā dhammā saṅghe pātubhavanti, atha satthā sāvakānaṁ sikkhāpadaṁ paññāpeti tesaṁyeva āsavaṭṭhānīyānaṁ dhammānaṁ paṭighātāya.
root_text.mn65:31.1: Na tāva, bhaddāli, idhekacce āsavaṭṭhānīyā dhammā saṅghe pātubhavanti yāva na saṅgho mahattaṁ patto hoti.
root_text.mn65:31.2: Yato ca kho, bhaddāli, saṅgho mahattaṁ patto hoti, atha idhekacce āsavaṭṭhānīyā dhammā saṅghe pātubhavanti.
root_text.mn65:31.3: Atha satthā sāvakānaṁ sikkhāpadaṁ paññāpeti tesaṁyeva āsavaṭṭhānīyānaṁ dhammānaṁ paṭighātāya.
root_text.mn65:31.4: Na tāva, bhaddāli, idhekacce āsavaṭṭhānīyā dhammā saṅghe pātubhavanti yāva na saṅgho lābhaggaṁ patto hoti, yasaggaṁ patto hoti, bāhusaccaṁ patto hoti, rattaññutaṁ patto hoti.
root_text.mn65:31.5: Yato ca kho, bhaddāli, saṅgho rattaññutaṁ patto hoti, atha idhekacce āsavaṭṭhānīyā dhammā saṅghe pātubhavanti, atha satthā sāvakānaṁ sikkhāpadaṁ paññāpeti tesaṁyeva āsavaṭṭhānīyānaṁ dhammānaṁ paṭighātāya.
root_text.mn65:32.1: Appakā kho tumhe, bhaddāli, tena samayena ahuvattha yadā vo ahaṁ ājānīyasusūpamaṁ dhammapariyāyaṁ desesiṁ.
root_text.mn65:32.5: “So hi nūnāhaṁ, bhante, dīgharattaṁ satthusāsane sikkhāya aparipūrakārī ahosin”ti.
root_text.mn65:32.6: “Na kho, bhaddāli, eseva hetu, esa paccayo.
root_text.mn65:32.7: Api ca me tvaṁ, bhaddāli, dīgharattaṁ cetasā cetoparicca vidito:
root_text.mn65:32.8: ‘na cāyaṁ moghapuriso mayā dhamme desiyamāne aṭṭhiṁ katvā manasi katvā sabbacetaso samannāharitvā ohitasoto dhammaṁ suṇātī’ti.
root_text.mn65:32.9: Api ca te ahaṁ, bhaddāli, ājānīyasusūpamaṁ dhammapariyāyaṁ desessāmi.
root_text.mn65:32.10: Taṁ suṇāhi, sādhukaṁ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī”ti.
root_text.mn65:32.11: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā bhaddāli bhagavato paccassosi.
root_text.mn65:33.1: “Seyyathāpi, bhaddāli, dakkho assadamako bhadraṁ assājānīyaṁ labhitvā paṭhameneva mukhādhāne kāraṇaṁ kāreti.
root_text.mn65:33.2: Tassa mukhādhāne kāraṇaṁ kāriyamānassa hontiyeva visūkāyitāni visevitāni vipphanditāni kānici kānici, yathā taṁ akāritapubbaṁ kāraṇaṁ kāriyamānassa.
root_text.mn65:33.3: So abhiṇhakāraṇā anupubbakāraṇā tasmiṁ ṭhāne parinibbāyati.
root_text.mn65:33.4: Yato kho, bhaddāli, bhadro assājānīyo abhiṇhakāraṇā anupubbakāraṇā tasmiṁ ṭhāne parinibbuto hoti, tamenaṁ assadamako uttari kāraṇaṁ kāreti yugādhāne.
root_text.mn65:33.5: Tassa yugādhāne kāraṇaṁ kāriyamānassa hontiyeva visūkāyitāni visevitāni vipphanditāni kānici kānici, yathā taṁ akāritapubbaṁ kāraṇaṁ kāriyamānassa.
root_text.mn65:33.6: So abhiṇhakāraṇā anupubbakāraṇā tasmiṁ ṭhāne parinibbāyati.
root_text.mn65:33.7: Yato kho, bhaddāli, bhadro assājānīyo abhiṇhakāraṇā anupubbakāraṇā tasmiṁ ṭhāne parinibbuto hoti, tamenaṁ assadamako uttari kāraṇaṁ kāreti anukkame maṇḍale khurakāse dhāve davatte rājaguṇe rājavaṁse uttame jave uttame haye uttame sākhalye.
root_text.mn65:33.8: Tassa uttame jave uttame haye uttame sākhalye kāraṇaṁ kāriyamānassa hontiyeva visūkāyitāni visevitāni vipphanditāni kānici kānici, yathā taṁ akāritapubbaṁ kāraṇaṁ kāriyamānassa.
root_text.mn65:33.9: So abhiṇhakāraṇā anupubbakāraṇā tasmiṁ ṭhāne parinibbāyati.
root_text.mn65:33.10: Yato kho, bhaddāli, bhadro assājānīyo abhiṇhakāraṇā anupubbakāraṇā tasmiṁ ṭhāne parinibbuto hoti, tamenaṁ assadamako uttari vaṇṇiyañca pāṇiyañca anuppavecchati.
root_text.mn65:33.11: Imehi kho, bhaddāli, dasahaṅgehi samannāgato bhadro assājānīyo rājāraho hoti rājabhoggo rañño aṅganteva saṅkhyaṁ gacchati.
root_text.mn65:34.1: Evameva kho, bhaddāli, dasahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṁ puññakkhettaṁ lokassa.
root_text.mn65:34.3: Idha, bhaddāli, bhikkhu asekhāya sammādiṭṭhiyā samannāgato hoti, asekhena sammāsaṅkappena samannāgato hoti, asekhāya sammāvācāya samannāgato hoti, asekhena sammākammantena samannāgato hoti, asekhena sammāājīvena samannāgato hoti, asekhena sammāvāyāmena samannāgato hoti, asekhāya sammāsatiyā samannāgato hoti, asekhena sammāsamādhinā samannāgato hoti, asekhena sammāñāṇena samannāgato hoti, asekhāya sammāvimuttiyā samannāgato hoti—
root_text.mn65:34.4: imehi kho, bhaddāli, dasahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṁ puññakkhettaṁ lokassā”ti.
root_text.mn65:34.6: Attamano āyasmā bhaddāli bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.

translation_text.mn65:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn65:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
translation_text.mn65:2.1: “Mendicants, I eat my food in one sitting per day.
translation_text.mn65:2.2: Doing so, I find that I’m healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.
translation_text.mn65:2.3: You too should eat your food in one sitting per day.
translation_text.mn65:2.4: Doing so, you’ll find that you’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.”
translation_text.mn65:3.1: When he said this, Venerable Bhaddāli said to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn65:3.2: “Sir, I’m not going to try to eat my food in one sitting per day.
translation_text.mn65:3.3: For when eating once a day I might feel remorse and regret.”
translation_text.mn65:4.1: “Well then, Bhaddāli, eat one part of the meal in the place where you’re invited, and bring the rest back to eat.
translation_text.mn65:4.2: Eating this way, too, you will sustain yourself.”
translation_text.mn65:4.3: “Sir, I’m not going to try to eat that way, either.
translation_text.mn65:4.4: For when eating that way I might also feel remorse and regret.”
translation_text.mn65:4.5: Then, as this rule was being laid down by the Buddha and the Saṅgha was undertaking it, Bhaddāli announced he would not try to keep it.
translation_text.mn65:4.6: Then for the whole of that three months Bhaddāli would not see the Buddha face to face, as happens when someone doesn’t fulfill the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.
translation_text.mn65:5.1: At that time several mendicants were making a robe for the Buddha, thinking that
translation_text.mn65:5.2: when his robe was finished and the three months of the rains residence had passed the Buddha would set out wandering.
translation_text.mn65:6.1: Then Bhaddāli went up to those mendicants, and exchanged greetings with them.
translation_text.mn65:6.2: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side. The mendicants said to Bhaddāli,
translation_text.mn65:6.3: “Reverend Bhaddāli, this robe is being made for the Buddha.
translation_text.mn65:6.4: When it’s finished and the three months of the rains residence have passed the Buddha will set out wandering.
translation_text.mn65:6.5: Come on, Bhaddāli, learn your lesson. Don’t make it hard for yourself later on.”
translation_text.mn65:7.1: “Yes, reverends,” Bhaddāli replied. He went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
translation_text.mn65:7.2: “I made a mistake, sir. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of me that, as this rule was being laid down by the Buddha and the Saṅgha was undertaking it, I announced I would not try to keep it.
translation_text.mn65:7.3: Please, sir, accept my mistake for what it is, so I will restrain myself in future.”
translation_text.mn65:8.1: “Indeed, Bhaddāli, you made a mistake. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of you that, as this rule was being laid down by the Buddha and the Saṅgha was undertaking it, you announced you would not try to keep it.
translation_text.mn65:9.1: And you didn’t realize this situation:
translation_text.mn65:9.2: ‘The Buddha is staying in Sāvatthī, and he’ll know me
translation_text.mn65:9.3: as the mendicant named Bhaddāli who doesn’t fulfill the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.’
translation_text.mn65:9.5: And you didn’t realize this situation:
translation_text.mn65:9.6: ‘Several monks have commenced the rains retreat in Sāvatthī …
translation_text.mn65:9.10: several nuns have commenced the rains retreat in Sāvatthī …
translation_text.mn65:9.18: several laywomen reside in Sāvatthī, and they’ll know me
translation_text.mn65:9.19: as the mendicant named Bhaddāli who doesn’t fulfill the training according to the Teacher’s instructions. …
translation_text.mn65:9.22: Several ascetics and brahmins who follow various other religions have commenced the rains retreat in Sāvatthī, and they’ll know me
translation_text.mn65:9.23: as the mendicant named Bhaddāli, one of the senior disciples of Gotama, who doesn’t fulfill the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.’
translation_text.mn65:9.24: You also didn’t realize this situation.”
translation_text.mn65:10.1: “I made a mistake, sir. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of me that, as this rule was being laid down by the Buddha and the Saṅgha was undertaking it, I announced I would not try to keep it.
translation_text.mn65:10.2: Please, sir, accept my mistake for what it is, so I will restrain myself in future.”
translation_text.mn65:10.3: “Indeed, Bhaddāli, you made a mistake. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of you that, as this rule was being laid down by the Buddha and the Saṅgha was undertaking it, you announced you would not try to keep it.
translation_text.mn65:11.2: Suppose I was to say this to a mendicant who is freed both ways:
translation_text.mn65:11.3: ‘Please, mendicant, be a bridge for me to cross over the mud.’ Would they cross over themselves, or struggle to get out of it, or just say no?”
translation_text.mn65:11.6: Suppose I was to say the same thing to a mendicant who is freed by wisdom,
translation_text.mn65:11.12: ‘Please, mendicant, be a bridge for me to cross over the mud.’ Would they cross over themselves, or struggle to get out of it, or just say no?”
translation_text.mn65:12.2: At that time were you freed both ways, freed by wisdom, a direct witness, attained to view, freed by faith, a follower of teachings, or a follower by faith?”
translation_text.mn65:13.3: Please, sir, accept my mistake for what it is, so I will restrain myself in future.”
translation_text.mn65:13.5: But since you have recognized your mistake for what it is, and have dealt with it properly, I accept it.
translation_text.mn65:13.6: For it is growth in the training of the Noble One to recognize a mistake for what it is, deal with it properly, and commit to restraint in the future.
translation_text.mn65:14.1: Bhaddāli, take a mendicant who doesn’t fulfill the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.
translation_text.mn65:14.3: ‘Why don’t I frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
translation_text.mn65:14.4: Hopefully I’ll realize a superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.’
translation_text.mn65:14.5: So they frequent a secluded lodging.
translation_text.mn65:14.6: While they’re living withdrawn, they’re reprimanded by the Teacher, by sensible spiritual companions after examination, by deities, and by themselves.
translation_text.mn65:14.7: Being reprimanded in this way, they don’t realize any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.
translation_text.mn65:14.9: Because that’s how it is when someone doesn’t fulfill the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.
translation_text.mn65:15.1: But take a mendicant who does fulfill the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.
translation_text.mn65:15.3: ‘Why don’t I frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
translation_text.mn65:15.4: Hopefully I’ll realize a superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.’
translation_text.mn65:15.5: They frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
translation_text.mn65:15.6: While they’re living withdrawn, they’re not reprimanded by the Teacher, by sensible spiritual companions after examination, by deities, or by themselves.
translation_text.mn65:15.7: Not being reprimanded in this way, they realize a superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.
translation_text.mn65:16.1: Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn65:16.3: Because that’s what happens when someone fulfills the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.
translation_text.mn65:17.1: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn65:17.3: Because that’s what happens when someone fulfills the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.
translation_text.mn65:17.4: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
translation_text.mn65:17.6: Because that’s what happens when someone fulfills the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.
translation_text.mn65:17.7: Furthermore, with the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
translation_text.mn65:17.9: Because that’s what happens when someone fulfills the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.
translation_text.mn65:18.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives.
translation_text.mn65:18.2: They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. … They recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
translation_text.mn65:18.4: Because that’s what happens when someone fulfills the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.
translation_text.mn65:19.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
translation_text.mn65:19.2: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. … they’re reborn in the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. … they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman … they understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.
translation_text.mn65:19.4: Because that’s what happens when someone fulfills the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.
translation_text.mn65:20.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
translation_text.mn65:20.2: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
translation_text.mn65:20.3: They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
translation_text.mn65:21.1: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
translation_text.mn65:21.2: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
translation_text.mn65:21.3: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’
translation_text.mn65:21.5: Because that’s what happens when someone fulfills the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.”
translation_text.mn65:22.1: When he said this, Venerable Bhaddāli said to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn65:22.2: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why they punish some monk, repeatedly pressuring him?
translation_text.mn65:22.3: And what is the cause, what is the reason why they don’t similarly punish another monk, repeatedly pressuring him?”
translation_text.mn65:23.1: “Take a monk who is a frequent offender with many offenses.
translation_text.mn65:23.2: When admonished by the monks, he dodges the issue, distracting the discussion with irrelevant points. He displays annoyance, hate, and bitterness. He doesn’t proceed properly, he doesn’t fall in line, he doesn’t proceed to get past it, and he doesn’t say: ‘I’ll do what pleases the Saṅgha.’
translation_text.mn65:23.3: In such a case, the monks say:
translation_text.mn65:23.4: ‘Reverends, this monk is a frequent offender, with many offenses.
translation_text.mn65:23.5: When admonished by the monks, he dodges the issue, distracting the discussion with irrelevant points. He displays annoyance, hate, and bitterness. He doesn’t proceed properly, he doesn’t fall in line, he doesn’t proceed to get past it, and he doesn’t say: “I’ll do what pleases the Saṅgha.”
translation_text.mn65:23.6: It’d be good for the venerables to examine this monk in such a way that this disciplinary issue is not quickly settled.’
translation_text.mn65:24.1: Take some other monk who is a frequent offender with many offenses.
translation_text.mn65:24.2: When admonished by the monks, he doesn’t dodge the issue, distracting the discussion with irrelevant points. He doesn’t display annoyance, hate, and bitterness. He proceeds properly, he falls in line, he proceeds to get past it, and he says: ‘I’ll do what pleases the Saṅgha.’
translation_text.mn65:24.3: In such a case, the monks say:
translation_text.mn65:24.4: ‘Reverends, this monk is a frequent offender, with many offenses.
translation_text.mn65:24.5: When admonished by the monks, he doesn’t dodge the issue, distracting the discussion with irrelevant points. He doesn’t display annoyance, hate, and bitterness. He proceeds properly, he falls in line, he proceeds to get past it, and he says: “I’ll do what pleases the Saṅgha.”
translation_text.mn65:24.6: It’d be good for the venerables to examine this monk in such a way that this disciplinary issue is quickly settled.’
translation_text.mn65:25.1: Take some other monk who is an occasional offender without many offenses.
translation_text.mn65:25.2: When admonished by the monks, he dodges the issue …
translation_text.mn65:25.3: In such a case, the monks say:
translation_text.mn65:25.4: ‘Reverends, this monk is an occasional offender without many offenses.
translation_text.mn65:25.5: When admonished by the monks, he dodges the issue …
translation_text.mn65:25.6: It’d be good for the venerables to examine this monk in such a way that this disciplinary issue is not quickly settled.’
translation_text.mn65:26.1: Take some other monk who is an occasional offender without many offenses.
translation_text.mn65:26.2: When admonished by the monks, he doesn’t dodge the issue …
translation_text.mn65:26.3: In such a case, the monks say:
translation_text.mn65:26.4: ‘Reverends, this monk is an occasional offender without many offenses.
translation_text.mn65:26.5: When admonished by the monks, he doesn’t dodge the issue …
translation_text.mn65:26.6: It’d be good for the venerables to examine this monk in such a way that this disciplinary issue is quickly settled.’
translation_text.mn65:27.1: Take some other monk who gets by with mere faith and love.
translation_text.mn65:27.2: In such a case, the monks say:
translation_text.mn65:27.3: ‘Reverends, this monk gets by with mere faith and love.
translation_text.mn65:27.4: Suppose we punish him, repeatedly pressuring him—
translation_text.mn65:27.5: no, let him not lose what little faith and love he has!’
translation_text.mn65:28.1: Suppose there was a person with one eye. Their friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would protect that one eye:
translation_text.mn65:28.2: ‘Let them not lose the one eye that they have!’
translation_text.mn65:28.3: In the same way, some monk gets by with mere faith and love.
translation_text.mn65:28.4: In such a case, the monks say:
translation_text.mn65:28.5: ‘Reverends, this monk gets by with mere faith and love.
translation_text.mn65:28.6: Suppose we punish him, repeatedly pressuring him—
translation_text.mn65:28.7: no, let him not lose what little faith and love he has!’
translation_text.mn65:28.8: This is the cause, this is the reason why they punish some monk, repeatedly pressuring him.
translation_text.mn65:28.9: And this is the cause, this is the reason why they don’t similarly punish another monk, repeatedly pressuring him.”
translation_text.mn65:29.1: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why there used to be fewer training rules but more enlightened mendicants?
translation_text.mn65:29.2: And what is the cause, what is the reason why these days there are more training rules and fewer enlightened mendicants?”
translation_text.mn65:30.1: “That’s how it is, Bhaddāli. When sentient beings are in decline and the true teaching is disappearing there are more training rules and fewer enlightened mendicants.
translation_text.mn65:30.2: The Teacher does not lay down training rules for disciples as long as certain defiling influences have not appeared in the Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn65:30.3: But when such defiling influences appear in the Saṅgha, the Teacher lays down training rules for disciples to protect against them.
translation_text.mn65:31.1: And they don’t appear until the Saṅgha has attained a great size,
translation_text.mn65:31.4: an abundance of material support and fame, learning, and seniority.
translation_text.mn65:31.5: But when the Saṅgha has attained these things, then such defiling influences appear in the Saṅgha, and the Teacher lays down training rules for disciples to protect against them.
translation_text.mn65:32.1: There were only a few of you there at the time when I taught the exposition on the simile of the thoroughbred colt.
translation_text.mn65:32.4: “What do you believe the reason for that is?”
translation_text.mn65:32.5: “Sir, it’s surely because for a long time now I haven’t fulfilled the training according to the Teacher’s instructions.”
translation_text.mn65:32.7: Rather, for a long time I have encompassed your mind and known:
translation_text.mn65:32.8: ‘While I’m teaching, this futile man doesn’t pay attention, apply the mind, concentrate wholeheartedly, or actively listen to the teaching.’
translation_text.mn65:32.9: Still, Bhaddāli, I shall teach the exposition on the simile of the thoroughbred colt.
translation_text.mn65:32.10: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.mn65:33.1: “Suppose a deft horse trainer were to obtain a fine thoroughbred. First of all he’d make it get used to wearing the bit.
translation_text.mn65:33.2: Because it has not done this before, it still resorts to some twists, ducks, and dodges.
translation_text.mn65:33.3: But with regular and gradual practice its bad behavior is extinguished.
translation_text.mn65:33.4: When it has done this, the horse trainer next makes it get used to wearing the harness.
translation_text.mn65:33.5: Because it has not done this before, it still resorts to some twists, ducks, and dodges.
translation_text.mn65:33.6: But with regular and gradual practice its bad behavior is extinguished.
translation_text.mn65:33.7: When it has done this, the horse trainer next makes it get used to walking in procession, circling, prancing, galloping, charging, the protocols and traditions of court, and in the very best speed, fleetness, and camaraderie.
translation_text.mn65:33.8: Because it has not done this before, it still resorts to some twists, ducks, and dodges.
translation_text.mn65:33.9: But with regular and gradual practice its bad behavior is extinguished.
translation_text.mn65:33.10: When it has done this, the horse trainer next rewards it with a grooming and a rub down.
translation_text.mn65:33.11: A fine royal thoroughbred with these ten factors is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and reckoned as a factor of kingship.
translation_text.mn65:34.1: In the same way, a mendicant with ten qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.
translation_text.mn65:34.3: It’s when a mendicant has an adept’s right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right immersion, right knowledge, and right freedom.
translation_text.mn65:34.4: A mendicant with these ten qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.”
translation_text.mn65:34.5: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn65:34.6: Satisfied, Venerable Bhaddāli approved what the Buddha said.
